before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"439jk","text":"Notes about PCR 1:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a0bu5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bb59j","text":"The first PCR in the gDNA amplification process is designed to both add adapter sequences to one end of the amplicon as well as cross the recombination junction.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5jc84","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cvh8","text":"The design of these primers should be such that the forward primer sits within the recombining plasmid and has a standard adapter sequence attached.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e3uha","text":"The reverse primer should sit within the landing pad (usually at the start of BFP).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2oa7d","text":"The use of these two primers, in these two locations, ensures that the only gDNA that gets amplified is gDNA from cells that have successfully recombined.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4begm","text":"○\t Unrecombined cells will not be able to bind the forward primer, and leftover plasmid will not bind the second primer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9aoc4","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1s7rn","text":"For this step, we run 8 identical reactions for two reasons:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgvls","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2jjbe","text":"To reduce “jackpotting” where a random polymerase error gets propagated through the sequencing run.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"647sj","text":"To ensure we use enough gDNA to cover our library, since gDNA is extremely large (\u003e6 billion bp) and thus has very few copies even in thousands of ng of gDNA.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vu7i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2flos","text":"The process for plasmid DNA is identical, but we use 10 ng plasmid DNA instead of 2500 ng gDNA in the reaction and we only do 1 reaction instead of 8.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16pna","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"budaf","text":"The reverse primer for plasmid DNA, since it does not need to span a recombination junction, uses a different reverse primer that contains an adapter sequence (just like the forward primer) – use NP0493.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4l6eg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9iqic","text":"Notes about AmPure XP cleanup:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4hru","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgi4n","text":"The amount of AmPure XP beads to use is dependent on the size of the amplicon that is being purified. Generally, AmPure XP cleans up smaller fragments, leaving larger ones to be eluted and saved.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pfuj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80ln9","text":"More beads allows smaller fragments to be retained.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vqp1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3kqae","text":"Notes about PCR 2:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"91iv1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ceu8","text":"The second PCR in the gDNA amplification process is designed to reduce the size of the final amplicon to one that will cluster well on Illumina (smaller amplicons perform better) as well as add the sample indices and cluster generator sequences that will be used by Illumina to sequence and demultiplex samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"43oml","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2pt53","text":"Each individual sample will require a separate pair of indices, one on the forward and one on the reverse primer.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4j9sv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6rhe","text":"○\t We usually have 14 distinct indices for the forward primer and 14 distinct indices for the reverse primer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7j1un","text":"The indexes can be combined to create up to 196 unique index combinations (14 forward x 14 reverse) to multiplex up to 196 samples on the same Illumina run.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dibg6","text":"In practice, we usually use less than 20 on a single Illumina run, which is entirely dependent on how many sequencing reads we need per sample compared to the number of sequencing reads produced by the Illumina kit.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"711ki","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8erjc","text":"○\tThe reverse primer will bind directly to the amplicon sequence and will contain a unique index and a cluster generator sequence (P7).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bm1n5","text":"This primer binds 5’ to the reverse primer in PCR1, since we need to reduce the size of the amplicon, usually to about 250-350 bases, for good Illumina sequencing.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9pup1","text":"If the location of the barcode changes for whichever reason, it’s necessary to change these primers to match that new location.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38q0i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9nl1h","text":"○\tThe forward primer will bind to the adapter sequence added in PCR1 and will contain a unique index and the other cluster generator sequence (P5).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"avol7","text":"The adapter sequence is designed such that we do not get amplification of any gDNA other than that which was amplified in PCR1. This ensures that we continue to not amplify random plasmid or gDNA that does not contain our barcoded region.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4m7q3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1l2uc","text":"For plasmid DNA, you will need to alter the reverse primer, since it has an adapter sequence to bind to.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"e25k","text":"This protocol details the gDNA amplification and plasmid DNA amplification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"1va3s","text":"This protocol will be written as if running a single sample through. Calculations will need to be made for any optimizations","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pvih","text":"Annealing temperature, extension time, annealing time, and DNA concentration are all parameters to be optimized for each PCR reaction","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ct9m","text":"Optimizations are best done at 10-20 mL and run on a 2% agarose gel","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8farr","text":"This protocol is written for either gDNA amplification or plasmid DNA amplification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cagso","text":"Differences will be noted in bold   ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":29,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"42gt0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
